2.3 Geographic distribution data
We obtained binary species distribution data (presence/absence) of palms from the geographic range maps of (Bjorholm et al. 2005) and on mammals from the IUCN (International Union for the Conservation of Nature) data portal. To generate local gridded multitrophic species assemblages across the Neotropics, we intersected the species-level range maps with a spatial grid where each grid cell represented a 1 \(\times\) 1 degree latitude and longitude resolution across the extent of the entire Neotropics. We then recorded all palm and mammal frugivore species occurring in each grid cell as our grid-cell level multitrophic assemblages.

2.3.1 Trait data
We collected species-level multitrophic trait data related to the physiological tolerance of palms and frugivorous mammals to the abiotic environment and to their mutualistic interactions. For palms, we extracted data from the PalmTraits 1.0 dataset (Kissling et al. 2019). We collected data on growth form, maximum stem height, and average fruit length. For frugivorous mammals, we obtained trait data from the EltonTraits 1.0 database (Wilman et al. 2014). We selected data on body mass, diet, and daily activities. Diet data from the EltonTraits 1.0 database is coded as percentage use distribution across ten diet categories. We excluded from our analysis species without fruit in their diet. Activity was coded as a dummy variable with three categories (Diurnal, Crepuscular, Nocturnal). Finally, body mass was coded as a numerical variable in kg. We excluded bats from the analysis as almost no Neotropical bat species is feeding on palm fruits (Messeder et al. 2020). From this dataset, we selected only those species whose geographic range in the 1×1° latitude grid co-occurred with at least 5 other palm and mammal frugivore species. In total, we worked with a set of 494 palm species and 488 mammal frugivore species with linked trait and geographic data, which comprised respectively ~61% (Roncal et al. 2013; Balslev, Bernal, and Fay 2016) and ~64% (Fuzessy and Pizo 2025) of reported species for the Neotropics .


2.3.2 Pairwise interaction data
We used data on seed dispersal interactions between palms and frugivorous mammals for the Neotropics, originating from recollections of seed dispersal records found in the published literature and interaction records recorded at the species level (Muñoz, Trøjelsgaard, and Kissling 2019). Each pairwise species interaction record reflects where an article mentions the fruit or the seed of a palm being dispersed, carried, or defecated by a frugivorous mammal. Interaction records collected in this database were previously vetted by (Muñoz, Trøjelsgaard, and Kissling 2019) to reflect effective seed dispersal interactions, while avoiding those that reflect mere seed consumption (vetting criteria found in: (Muñoz, Trøjelsgaard, and Kissling 2019)). In total, we gathered a total of 581 interaction records between 69 palms and 111 frugivore mammals.


2.3.3 Climatic data
We used bioclimatic variables from WorldClim (Fick and Hijmans 2017) to represent large-scale spatial and temporal variation of climate in the Neotropics. Specifically, we used mean annual temperature (BIO01), total annual precipitation (BIO12), temperature seasonality (BIO04), and precipitation seasonality (BIO15). We selected these variables to represent the main axes of environmental niche variation shared by palms and frugivorous mammals (representing 91% of the total variance contained in the 19 WorldClim BIOCLIM variables). To harmonize spatial resolution with the scale of ecological analyses, each selected raster layer was aggregated by averaging approximately 34 neighboring cells into one while preserving broad-scale climatic gradients relevant to the study (i.e. 1 \(\times\) 1 degree grid resolution).


2.3.4 Statistical analysis

2.3.4.1 Building a probabilistic Neotropical metaweb from aggregated binary interaction records
We fitted latent variable network structural models (Rohr et al. 2010; Terry and Lewis 2020) based on different underlying assumptions to infer interaction probabilities from binary observations of species interactions (Figure 3). Specifically, we tested the stochastic block model, the connectance model, the trait-matching model, and the matching-centrality model (Terry and Lewis 2020). The stochastic block model assumes that ecological networks are modular, with species of consumers interacting more within their preferred groups of producers (i.e., interaction guilds) than outside their preferred groups. This model outputs three incidence matrices, reflecting predicted interactions: (i) one with guilds of palm species based on their modular interactions with mammals, (ii) a similar one for mammals, and (iii) one representing the interaction probabilities (Theta) among the guilds of each group (i.e., palm guilds and mammal guilds, respectively). The connectance model posits that interactions of specialist species are subsets of those of generalist species and optimizes connectivity scores, constrained by this assumption, to recreate observed network patterns. The trait-matching model assumes non-random species interactions determined by trait differences, optimizing parameters along latent-trait axes. Finally, the matching-centrality model combines connectivity scores and latent-trait axes (Terry and Lewis 2020). Additional details about the model assumptions are explained in Supplementary B1. We fitted these models to our available interaction data and selected the model that best predicted the observed Neotropical pattern of seed dispersal interactions. Using Youden’s J as a metric that balanced model sensitivity and specificity (Poisot 2023), we found that the stochastic block model was the best supported model (Figure 3) and therefore focus on it in the rest of the manuscript.



Figure 3: Evaluation of four network assembly models to predict the binary structure of observed palm-mammal frugivory interactions in the Neotropics. (a) Region under the Curve (ROC) curves, (b,c) Youden’s J index, and (d) clustering heatmaps. The four models are the Centrality Model (CM), Trait Matching Model (TMM), Matching Centrality Model (MCM), and Stochastic Block Model (SBM). The ROC curves in (a) assess model performance through the relationship between model sensitivity (i.e. true positive rate) and model specificity (true negative rate). The curves above the diagonal demonstrate stronger predictive ability, showing that the model performs significantly better than random guesses in identifying ecological interactions. If a ROC curve is close to or below this diagonal, the model’s predictive performance is no better than random. The boxplot in (b) summarizes the Youden’s J index for each network assembly model, where higher values reflect higher overall predictive accuracy. In (c), the Youden’s J index shows variation over different probability thresholds to specify binary interactions. In (d), heatmaps highlight structural differences among the four models.




2.3.4.2 Identifying interactions guilds
The hyperparameters of the Stochastic Block Model provided the best fit for capturing the observed interactions, suggesting that palm - frugivorous mammal interaction networks are highly modular. Certain groups of producers were thus more likely to interact with certain groups of consumers than others, and vice versa. In this context, we define an interaction guild as a distinct group of palm and frugivorous mammal species within the Neotropical metaweb that exhibits similar interaction patterns, forming a module. Within each guild, both producer and resource species perform comparable functional roles in the network. Within and between each guild combination of consumers and producers, species pairs exhibit the same interaction strength, where interaction strength is defined as the magnitude or intensity of the effect that one species has on another within an ecological network. Here we estimate interaction strength as the probability that a species pair would interact in nature. The stochastic block model estimates such interaction probabilities based on the frequency of interactions observed between species assigned to a given guild of consumer or producer. The stochastic block model uses maximum likelihood to adjust the number of guilds and the distribution of interaction probabilities within and between guilds such that they best explain the observed pattern of interactions. Using stochastic block models largely reduces the complexity of dealing with pairwise interaction strengths by treating them as a guild-level phenomenon instead of a species-specific one. Importantly, there is no restriction for the stochastic model to assign palm or mammal species to every guild; consequently, some guilds may contain zero species within the Neotropical metaweb or a given grid cell. Our approach resulted in a theta matrix representing 7 x 7 latent guild combinations. In addition, we obtained a guild-association matrix for each trophic level. For frugivorous mammals, five guilds (guilds 1, 3, 4, 6, and 7) had at least one mammal species and two inferred guilds with no mammal species allocated to them (a.k.a empty guilds: 2, 5). For palms, we obtained four guilds (guilds 2, 3, 5, and 6) allocating at least one palm species and three empty guilds (1,3,7).


2.3.4.3 Downscaling the Neotropical metaweb to generate grid-cell level networks
The availability of primary biodiversity data on palms and their frugivorous mammals was imbalanced, with a high availability of distribution ranges and species traits, but a limited number of interaction records. We therefore used a two-fold approach to downscale the initial, Neotropical metaweb to include interactions between every potentially co-occurring palm and mammal frugivore in every grid cell across the Neotropics.
First, we employed multinomial logistic regression models using neural networks to predict the interaction guild affiliation of each species from the stochastic block model results using species-level trait data. We justify the choice of multinomial logistic regression models as these can handle the prediction of non-binary outcomes, such as the labeling of interaction guilds per species. Separate multinomial logistic regression models using a single-hidden layer network were fitted for palms and frugivorous mammals, respectively (Ripley, Venables, and Ripley 2016) with 75% of the data allocated for training and the remaining 25% for testing. This approach is useful when dealing with multicollinearity, as it can learn complex and non-linear relationships and interactions among multiple predictor variables. This allowed us to separate the relative importance of distinct matching traits from the stochastic block model group affiliations. We extracted variable importance scores based on combinations of the absolute values of the best fit model weights (Gevrey, Dimopoulos, and Lek 2003).
Second, we considered local pairwise species interaction probabilities as the product of the values from the Theta matrix from the stochastic block model that represents the latent interaction probabilities between species pairs within and between guilds multiplied by their probability of co-occurrence in a grid cell. To represent species’ co-occurrence probabilities, we calculated a spatial overlap index for each species pair as the product of their relative range areas, normalized by the sum of their areas. Additionally, we computed the geographic distance between species’ range centroids and rescaled these distances to a 0–1 scale, with proximity increasing interaction weight. The final interaction weight for each species pair was computed as the product of the rescaled SBM-derived probability, the rescaled spatial overlap index, and the inverse of the rescaled geographic distance. In other words, grid-level interaction probabilities represent the biological feasibility of a pairwise interaction given the regional availability of their traits (Strydom et al. 2022), with the overall assumption of higher species abundances toward the center of their geographic ranges (Schmidt et al. 2022)


2.3.4.4 Estimating functional richness
Functional richness (FR) is typically defined as the variability and relative frequency of functional traits within a community (Kraft, Valencia, and Ackerly 2008; Kraft and Ackerly 2010). The interaction guilds identified by the stochastic block model encapsulate unique combinations of functional traits reflected in species interactions. Consequently, the guild affiliation itself represents a categorical multitrophic “functional trait syndrome” for our analysis. For each grid cell, we calculated the proportion of palm and mammal species belonging to each guild (n = 7) relative to the total number of palm or mammal species present locally. This normalization ensures that our measure reflects trait diversity rather than simply species richness. Thus, our metric of FR quantifies the diversity of functional roles occupied by palms and mammals within local networks, aligning conceptually with broader ecological definitions of FR but adapted to multitrophic assemblages through the latent trait representation provided by the stochastic block model. We assigned a value of FR = 0 to those guilds with no palm or mammal species present.


2.3.4.5 Estimating functional trophic asymmetry
We quantified FTA as the absolute difference in functional richness between palm and frugivorous mammal assemblages within each of the 1,242 grid cells. The FTA measure for each grid cell was obtained by computing the absolute difference between guild-specific functional richness values across the two trophic levels, resulting in one FTA value per guild combination per grid cell. This approach resulted in 43 unique realized pairwise guild combinations, after excluding 6 combinations where both guilds lacked species representation in the Neotropical metaweb. Overall, 98% of all available guild combinations exhibited nonzero FTA values across grid cells, indicating that only 2% of potential palm–mammal guild interactions from the metaweb were locally absent. To estimate a single grid-cell level metric of functional trophic asymmetry, we summed the FTA values across all interaction guilds, weighted by their respective interaction strengths (FTAsum). This approach was chosen as it accounts for the uneven contributions of each guild to network structure.


2.3.4.6 Estimating network specialization
We estimated network specialization for each grid cell using the metric H2’. H2’ is a network-level index that varies between 0 and 1 (Blüthgen et al. 2007). High values indicate networks that are more specialized, meaning that species from one trophic level interact with only one or just a few species in the other trophic level. Low H2’ values indicate that there is a low specificity of interactions in the network, meaning that species from one trophic level interact with multiple species of the other trophic level. Because inferred networks varied in their network size (i.e., number of unique interactions between palms and frugivorous mammals), we rarefied the H2’ computed for each grid-cell level network such that they would all have the same size (i.e., number of interactions). Specifically, we rarefied all networks to 100 pairwise interactions and repeated the procedure 999 times to get a distribution of rarefied H2’ values (Terry and Lewis 2020). We then selected the median of this H2’ distribution as our grid cell-level measure of network specialization.


2.3.4.7 Assessing the influence of climate on FTA
To assess whether climate has an influence on FTA, we fitted a Generalized Additive Model (GAM) to examine the relationships between FTA and the four bioclimatic predictors described above. The GAM approach allows for modelling flexible non-linear relationships between the predictors and the response variable using smoothed penalized functions (Wood 2017). We fitted separate splines for each climatic predictor.


2.3.4.8 Assessing how interaction strength mediates the influence of climate on FTA
In our approach, interaction strength represents the estimated frequency of interactions between species assigned to a given guild of consumer or producer, that is, the values from the theta matrix from the SBM (Figure S1). To assess whether the strength of interactions between producer and consumer guilds mediates the relationship between FTA and climate, we included “interaction strength” as an interaction term in the GAM, allowing splines between FTA and climate to vary non-linearly depending on the strength of interaction among guilds.


2.3.4.9 Assessing the relationship between FTA and H2’
We used a GAM to investigate the relationship between rarefied grid-cell network specialization (H2’) as a response variable and FTA (z-scores) as the main predictor. We also added covariate functions to account for the effect of mean annual temperature, total annual precipitation, precipitation seasonality, and temperature seasonality because these climate variables may influence H2’ independently of FTA. This allowed us to isolate the specific impact of FTA on H2’ while controlling for the indirect effects of climate on FTA.

2.4 Results

2.4.1 Interaction guild delineation
The result of our modelling approach was one theta matrix reflecting the modular pattern of interaction guilds in the Neotropical metaweb (Figure S1) and two association matrices linking frugivorous mammals (Figure S2a) and palms (Figure S2b) to their interaction guilds. Together, they represent high-level trait-trait associations between trophic levels. Specifically: a) Tall palms with medium-sized fruits (p3) are strongly associated with small to medium sized mammals that consume moderate to high amounts of fruit (m1). b) Acaulescent or small-stemmed palms with small to large fruits (p6) correlate strongly with small mammals with relatively low frugivory (m3). Finally, c) medium-sized to large sized frugivorous mammals with moderate to low frugivory levels (m6) interact with moderately tall erect palms with medium-sized fruits (p5). Our approach resulted in 1287 grid cells across the Neotropics, each containing seven measures of functional richness (FR) for palms and seven measures for mammals, corresponding to each interaction guild within the two trophic levels. Across all grid cells, mammalian frugivore guild m3 dominated (54 % ± 9), comprising 341 species of relatively small-bodied frugivores (mean 4.75 ± 1.33 kg) with low fruit intake (21.7 ± 7.2 %) and predominantly nocturnal habits (84 % nocturnal, 22 % diurnal). Its counterpart in palms (p3) was much smaller (just 15 species) but consisted of the tallest stems (3.45 ± 0.26 m) bearing the largest fruits (1.69 ± 0.40 cm). Mammalian frugivore guild m6 (15 % ± 5) included 15 of the largest frugivores (9.73 ± 0.73 kg) with moderate frugivory (20 ± 12.5 %) and mixed activity patterns (40 % diurnal, 73 % nocturnal, 47 % crepuscular); its counterpart palm assemblage (p6) (137 species) was dominated by short‐stemmed, large‐fruited forms (1.18 ± 0.96 m; 1.39 ± 0.57 cm) with a high proportion of acaulescent growth (36 %). Smaller frugivorous mammal assemblages in mammalian guilds m1 (12 % ± 4) and m7 (10 % ± 4) comprised 66 and 33 species, respectively: m1 species were moderately sized (6.47 ± 1.68 kg), highly frugivorous (64.1 ± 11.6 %) and evenly split between diurnal and nocturnal, whereas m7 species were larger (8.15 ± 0.52 kg), moderately frugivorous (36.4 ± 4.9 %) and mostly diurnal (79 %). Guild m4 (9 % ± 5) included 33 small (3.91 ± 0.66 kg), highly frugivorous mammals (48.5 ± 3.6 %) that were almost exclusively nocturnal (97 %). Among palms, guild p5 dominated (46 % ± 15) with 265 low‐stature (understory), erect stemmed palms (1.95 ± 0.63 m; 0.90 ± 0.31 cm fruits; 1 % acaulescent), followed by guild p6 (34 % ± 18) and guild p3 (10 % ± 7), while guilds p1, p4 and p7 had no palm representatives (Table S4, Figure S2a, S2b).


2.4.2 Assessing the influence of climate on functional richness
Overall, the functional richness of palm interaction guilds showed a weak association with climatic gradients (Table S1, Figure S3). Only mean annual temperature had a significant positive effect (estimate = 4.07e−04, P = 0.0027), while precipitation (P = 0.23), temperature seasonality (P = 0.79), and precipitation seasonality (P = 0.50) showed no significant effects (Table S1). In contrast, the functional richness of mammal interaction guilds was significantly and positively related to temperature (estimate = 4.42e−04, P < 0.001), but unrelated to precipitation (P = 0.15), temperature seasonality (P = 0.63), or precipitation seasonality (P = 0.13) (Table S2). However, when using smoothed terms for separating the effects of climate across individual interaction guilds, we found significant correlations (Table S1). Mean annual temperature had a significant nonlinear effect for palm guild p3 (F = 6.30, P = 0.014), whose functional richness declined with increasing temperature. Several other guilds (m1, m4, m5, m7) showed marginally significant temperature effects (P < 0.1), but responses were weak and inconsistent in direction. Significant precipitation effects were only observed for palm guild p6 (F = 2.95, P = 0.0067), which showed a positive association, indicating increased functional richness of short-stemmed or acaulescent palms in wetter environments. No other guilds showed a statistically significant relationship with precipitation. For precipitation seasonality, statistically significant responses were observed for palm guild p5 (F = 8.37, P = 0.0070) and IG-6 (F = 5.62, P = 0.0011). These had opposite directions: p5 functional richness decreased with higher seasonality, while it increased for p6. No guild showed statistically significant effects of temperature seasonality (P > 0.35 for all) (Figure 4a, Figure S1, Table S1). At the opposite trophic level, mean annual temperature emerged as the only statistically significant climatic driver, with significant nonlinear effects for mammalian guilds m1 (F = 6.66, P = 0.011), m2 (F = 6.91, P = 0.010), m4 (F = 11.21, P = 0.001), m5 (F = 6.91, P = 0.010), m6 (F = 10.33, P = 0.0016), and m7 (F = 9.02, P = 0.0032). Visual inspection of the partial effect plots revealed that all statistically significant guilds exhibited declining functional richness with increasing temperature, suggesting a negative nonlinear response within guilds (Figure 4a, Figure S1, Table S2).



Figure 4. Relationships between environmental gradients and functional richness, functional trophic asymmetry of mutualistic palm-mammal frugivore networks in the Neotropics. Figure panels a and b illustrate how functional richness (left) and functional trophic asymmetry (FTA; right) of palm–mammal frugivore guilds vary along two climatic gradients. In panel a (top), mammal guilds (red lines) show relatively flat functional richness across mean annual temperature, whereas palm guilds (green lines) diverge: guild IG-3p increases sharply toward warmer areas while IG-5m and IG-6m remain constant. In the lower‐left panel, functional richness declines with increasing precipitation seasonality in mammal guilds IG-3m, IG-4m, and IG-7m, but palm guild IG-6p increases, reflecting a shift toward more functionally diverse short‐stemmed species under seasonal rainfall. Panel b (top) reveals that FTA of certain mammal‐only guilds (e.g. m3p3 in yellow and m3p6 in red) steadily rises with temperature, while other guilds remain unchanged. The bottom‐right panel shows a more complex mosaic under precipitation seasonality, with some guilds (m5p6, m4p6) displaying stronger asymmetry in highly seasonal environments and others (m1p6, m7p6) remaining stable. Together, these plots underscore that palms and mammalian frugivores respond idiosyncratically to climatic gradients, and that the balance of their trait distributions can be either buffered or exacerbated by temperature and rainfall seasonality depending on the interaction guild.




2.4.3 Assessing the influence of climate on functional trophic asymmetry
The distribution of grid cell measures of functional trophic asymmetry varied significantly among interaction guilds in palm–mammal frugivore networks (Figures 4b). The highest asymmetries were observed in guild combinations (m = mammals, p = palms) such as m3p7, m3p4, and m3p1, indicating strong differences between functional traits of palms and associated mammalian frugivores. In contrast, guilds like m7p2, m4p3, and m7p3 showed markedly lower functional trophic asymmetry values (Figure S4). The weighted sum of guild-level Functional Trophic Asymmetry (FTAsum), which summarizes FTA variation across all interaction guilds, averaged 0.91 across all grid cells (SD = 0.10), with values ranging from 0.67 to 1.28 (Figure S6). FTAsum was positively correlated with mean annual temperature and precipitation seasonality. In other words, greater differences in the functional richness between trophic levels peaked in warm and regions with seasonal rainfall (Figure 5, Figure 6). Functional trophic asymmetry was positively related to mean annual temperature across all interaction guilds (F = 5.97, P = 0.01). However, no consistent relationships were found with precipitation (F = 0.28, P = 0.13), precipitation seasonality (F = 0.30, P = 0.59), or temperature seasonality (F = 0.19, P = 0.67) (Table 1).



Figure 5: Spatial variation of functional trophic asymmetry (FTAsum) and network-level specialization (H2′) across the Neotropics. Panels a & b shows the spatial variation of climatic predictors, i.e. (a) mean annual temperature, and (b) precipitation seasonality. Panel (c) shows FTAsum, which quantifies the disparity in functional richness between interacting trophic levels, with higher values (red) indicating greater asymmetry. Panel (d) displays H2′, a standardized measure of interaction specialization, where higher values (red) represent more specialized networks. The figure illustrates how broad‐scale climate gradients shape overall functional‐trait mismatch (FTAsum) and network specialisation (H2′) in Neotropical palm–mammal frugivore assemblages. In panel a, mean annual temperature (MAT) peaks above 28 °C in lowland Amazonia and Atlantic Forest and falls below 10 °C in the high Andes, while precipitation seasonality (PS) is lowest (< 30 mm) in the ever-wet Amazon and exceeds 120 mm in seasonally dry forests.





Figure 6: The variation of functional trophic asymmetry and network specialization for palm-mammal frugivore seed dispersal networks across climatic gradients in the Neotropics. Panels show partial effects (±95 % CI) of a generalized additive model: FTAsum increases steadily with mean annual temperature, indicating greater functional trophic asymmetry in warmer areas, but is effectively flat across the precipitation seasonality gradient. By contrast, H2′ remains low and invariant up to ~18 °C before rising at higher mean annual temperature, increasing monotonically with precipitation seasonality, indicating more specialised interactions under pronounced rainfall seasonality.




2.4.4 Assessing how interaction strength mediates the influence of climate on functional trophic asymmetry
The strength of interactions between guilds of consumers and producers had an overall positive but weak effect on functional trophic asymmetry (Figure 4b, Figure S7, Table S3). Moreover, we did not find strong evidence supporting that the relationship between functional trophic asymmetry and climate depends on the strength of interaction between interaction guilds (F = 746, P > 0.05) (Figure S7, Table 1). The interaction term between guild interaction strength and precipitation seasonality had a marginally significant positive effect on functional trophic asymmetry (F = 0.14, P = 0.051) (Figure S8, Table 1). Assessing the relationship between functional trophic asymmetry and network specialization We found that palm–mammal frugivore networks exhibited moderate to occasionally high levels of trophic specialization, with H2′ values ranging from 0.08 to 0.79 (median = 0.21), where 0 means that species have no preference for their interaction partners and 1 represents specialized networks where each species interacts only with a specific subset of interaction partners (Figure S9). H2′ was positively associated with the functional trophic asymmetry index (FTAsum) (β = 0.047, P = 0.002; Table S3), indicating that networks with greater asymmetry between consumer and resource traits tended to be more specialized (Figure 6, Figure S9). In addition, H2′ was significantly related to mean annual temperature (F = 3.39, P = 0.005) and precipitation seasonality (F = 3.13, P = 0.003), suggesting that environmental gradients shape patterns of trophic specialization (Figure 6). In contrast, H2′ showed no significant association with temperature seasonality or total annual precipitation (P > 0.2). The full model explained 4.5% of the H2’ deviance.

text:
2.5 Discussion
Our study reveals that the functional traits relevant to trophic interactions are subject to different relative strengths of environmental filtering among trophic levels, and over space in the Neotropics. In palm-mammal frugivore assemblages, these differences (a.k.a. functional trophic asymmetry) reach their maximum in areas with warm climates and highly seasonal precipitations. Furthermore, multitrophic species assemblages with high FTA paradoxically exhibited a high level of specialization in their trophic interaction networks. Taken together, our results suggest that distinct community assembly processes operate across trophic levels, reinforcing the idea that network assembly emerges from a dynamic interplay of bottom-up (producer driven) and top-down (consumer driven) processes (Moretti and Legg 2009); Marjakangas et al. (2022); Schleuning, Garcı́a, and Tobias (2023)] , whose respective contributions are dependent on the environmental and biotic conditions.

2.5.1 Contrasting trait-mediated responses to environmental variation across trophic levels
Consumer and producer assemblages are known to differ in their functional response to climatic gradients (Moretti and Legg 2009; Dehling et al. 2014; Albrecht and Schleuning 2018; Song and Spaak 2024). In our Neotropical palm-frugivore study system, changes in functional trophic asymmetry along the temperature gradient were primarily driven by consumers (mammalian frugivores), reflecting an increased representation of frugivores with a low proportion of fruit in their diet in warmer are-as. Along with the precipitation seasonality gradient, shifts in functional trophic asymmetry were producer-driven, linked to a decline in short-stature (understory) palms with low to medium fruit sizes and a concurrent rise in short-stemmed (acaulescent) palms bearing medium to large fruits (Figure 4). For mammalian frugivores, functional richness generally responded to the tempera-ture gradient, except for the guild representing small-bodied frugivores (IG-3), which exhibited relative stability across the gradient. These small-bodied frugivores can be primarily seed preda-tors rather than effective seed dispersers. As such, they may also be contributing more to antag-onistic than mutualistic outcomes in palm–frugivore interactions (Marques Dracxler and Kissling 2022) (Table S1). Palm responses are more tightly coupled to variation in precipitation seasonality and total annual precipitation, with both the shape and strength of these responses varying among guilds. Notably, there is a functional shift towards warmer regions with high precipitation seasonality, where palms with relatively small fruits (p5) are replaced by palms bearing relatively large fruits (p6). This pattern is consistent with previous studies showing that palm assemblages in regions with strong climatic seasonality and long dry periods tend to have larger fruit sizes in addition to a reduced species richness, likely an adaptive response to historical climatic fluctuations during the Quaternary (Kissling et al. 2012; Göldel, Kissling, and Svenning 2015).


2.5.2 Top-down and bottom-up variations in functional trophic asymmetry are mediated by climate
Functional trophic asymmetry varied geographically, peaking in warm regions with high seasonal precipitation. Overall, average annual temperature has a small but positive effect on functional trophic asymmetry. The effect on functional trophic asymmetry was explained by larger temperature-driven shifts in the functional richness of mammals than in that of palms. These results support the view that the assembly of palm-frugivore networks inhabiting the warmest regions of the Neotropics is predominantly top-down (i.e., consumer-driven). In contrast, the detected influence of precipitation seasonality on the functional richness of palm assemblages supports the view that the assembly of palm- mammalian sfrugivore networks in areas with highly seasonal precipitations is mostly bottom-up (i.e., producer-driven) (Schleuning et al. 2016; Albrecht and Schleuning 2018; Marjakangas et al. 2022; Dehling et al. 2020).
Interaction strength, that is, the intensity of the effect that one species has on another within an ecological network, varies strongly across palms and mammalian frugivore guilds. Moreover, variations in the strength of interaction among palm-frugivore guilds mediate the response of functional trophic asymmetry to precipitation seasonality. Specifically, the level of functional trophic asymmetry in strongly interacting guilds shows a more significant and positive relationship with precipitation seasonality. This means, for example, that palm species from guilds with more specialized seed dispersal are more common while palm species from guilds with a generalist seed dispersal strategy become rarer towards regions where rainfall is seasonal (Figure 4b, Figure 6). As precipitation becomes more seasonal, Neotropical palms are represented by species with larger fruits (Kissling et al. 2012) and mammalian frugivores with a broad diet become scarcer. For instance, the biomass of frugivorous primates is generally lower in seasonal environments with marked fruiting periods (Hanya et al. 2011). Our results align with findings of bat-plant mutualistic pollination networks, where interacting species exhibit lower niche overlaps in highly seasonal environments, and with those of avian-frugivory networks where weaker trait matching is found towards the tropics (Schleuning et al. 2012; Huang, Dalsgaard, and Chen 2025). They also contrast with others that report stronger trait-matching and interaction strength towards the tropics in plant-hummingbird pollination networks (Sonne et al. 2020) and avian-palm frugivory networks (McFadden et al. 2022). While our results are directly relevant to palm-mammal seed dispersal interactions, the diversity of process across mutualistic systems highlights the context dependency of trait–interaction-climate relationships. As such, generalizations about the functional ecology of mutualistic networks should pay attention to partner identity and interaction type.


2.5.3 Functional trophic asymmetry as a multitrophic indicator of ecological processes and their response to global changes
The concept of functional trophic asymmetry offers a valuable framework to examine how multitrophic ecological communities respond to shifting environmental conditions. Functional trophic asymmetry captures how environmental filtering differentially affects producers and consumers, revealing the contributions of bottom-up and top-down processes in shaping ecological network structure. While past studies have largely focused on single-trophic responses to climate or trait matching within networks, the framework we present here combines network assembly modeling with trait-based analyses, facilitating the generation of multiscale synthetic species interaction data, as well as ecological interpretations of broad-scale multitrophic community assembly pat-terns within a single framework. In addition to climate change, habitat destruction, defaunation, and other human-induced landscape modifications can independently alter resource and consumer functional diversity, thereby affecting functional trophic asymmetry (Guevara et al. 2023; Bello, Schleuning, and Graham 2023; Guerra et al. 2025). Although differences in the extent of landscape modification were not directly investigated in this study, previous research in plant-hummingbird mutualisms (i.e. pollination) shows that deforestation has a greater impact on the diversity and redundancy of functional roles in plants than in their pollinators, suggesting a de-cline in plant functional roles as forests are lost (Tinoco, Santillán, and Graham 2018; Guevara et al. 2023).
Future work may focus on integrating additional information such as geographic variation in population density, land-use change, or spatial movement data (e.g., GPS tracking of frugivores) that would improve realism and generalization of our modelling approach to generate synthetic ecological networks (Borah and Beckman 2022; Beumer et al. 2025; Cousens et al. 2010). For instance, the assumption of higher species abundances toward the center of geographic ranges could be challenged, as spatial patterns in species abundance might depend on how geographic ranges are aligned with background environmental gradients (Schmidt et al. 2022). Moreover, the role and importance of some individual consumer species in plant-animal seed dispersal networks (e.g. species’ centrality) might vary with the distance to their climatic niche centroid, suggesting the existence of areas where ecological and evolutionary dynamics might be elevated (Moulatlet et al. 2025). New elements such as these could be integrated into the analytical pipelines once sufficient relevant data becomes digitally available.

2.6 Conclusion
As climate change accelerates, rising temperatures and altered precipitation regimes are likely to increase functional trophic asymmetry in multitrophic palm-frugivore communities and increase specialization in palm seed dispersal networks. A likely consequence is also the loss of ecosystem function, in particular the zoochorous dispersal of palm propagules between habitat patches, which has been shown to decrease with increased specialization and reduced plant functional diversity (Landim et al. 2025). Such structural changes may also arise in other mutualistic net-work systems supporting key ecosystem functions, including pollination, myrmecochory, and plant-soil microbiome networks (Schleuning et al. 2014; schleuning2020trait?). These could similarly experience reduced functional connectivity and lower resilience due to increased specialization and declining functional diversity under climate change (Donoso et al. 2017; CaraDonna et al. 2021; Cruz et al. 2023). However, future research should explicitly test these predictions across different ecological systems to better understand the generality and scale of these impacts (Landim et al. 2025, 2025; Rabeau et al. 2025; Acosta-Rojas et al. 2023). As species distributions shift in response to climate change (Aizen, Sabatino, and Tylianakis 2012; Valiente-Banuet et al. 2015; Bartley et al. 2019; Hurtado, Montoya, and Stouffer 2024), our work showcases the potential role of functional trophic asymmetry as a key framework to advance our ability to predict shifts in ecosystem function (Montoya, Pimm, and Solé 2010; Bello et al. 2023; Heilmeier 2019) with incomplete multi-trophic data on species interactions and traits.

title: 3  Historical Paleoclimates and the Genesis of Regional Biotas
text:
3.1 Introduction
The biological diversity we see today has assembled over millions of years with evolutionary processes unfolding together with global climate change across geological time. Yet, modern studies investigating the effects of climate change on biodiversity assembly often share a focus on contemporary patterns and processes (Ackerly 2003; Kraft et al. 2015; Harrison, Spasojevic, and Li 2020). Although it is possible to derive some inference on the role of long-term evolutionary and historical processes from “one-time snapshots” of current biodiversity patterns  (Harrison, Spasojevic, and Li 2020; Chang and HilleRisLambers 2016), these contemporary patterns offer limited insights (Cadotte & Tucker 2017; Emerson & Gillespie 2008; Jackson & Blois 2015; Blois et al., 2014). A better understanding of evolutionary and historical processes is critical for biogeography, which focuses on the assembly of biodiversity at broad spatial scale (Cornell & Harrison 2014). The formation of global biogeographic regions, for example, is often attributed to plate tectonics movement and historical climate (Mazel et al., 2017). Nevertheless, the growing availability of spatially and temporally explicit biodiversity and paleoclimatic data, despite their heterogeneity and noise, creates an opportunity infer and model biodiversity assembly processes in deep time  (Kocsis et al., 2021; Briega-Alvarez et al., 2025).
Over deep time, influences on modern biodiversity can be tracked in repeated episodes of extinction, diversification, and biodiversity reorganization (Albert & Carvalho 2011; Morales-Garcia 2020; Daru et al., 2017). Fossil records in deep time provide a window into those evolutionary episodes (Jackson & Blois 2015; DiMichele et al., 2004; Erwin 2009) and additional insights into processes that extend well beyond the Quaternary (0-2.8Ma) (Blanco et al. 2021; Mottl et al. 2021; Jabot et al. 2020). Digitally available fossil datasets with geo-chrono-referenced fossil records (e.g. NOW, PBDB fossil databases) (Vzliobaite et al., 2023) open new opportunities for modelling the assembly of biodiversity across the geological time scale (Jablonski & Shubin 2015; Blanco et al. 2021; Mottl et al. 2021; Jabot et al. 2020). When integrated with spatiotemporal paleoclimatic reconstructions, these fossil records can reveal how planetary climate change shaped biodiversity in the absence anthropogenic stressors (Chang & HilleRisLambers 2016; DiMichele et al., 2004; Lyons & Wagner 2009).
At least two complementary attributes of paleoclimatic dynamics could have influenced the assembly of regional biodiversity in deep time. First, the magnitude of directional climatic change between adjacent geological periods, expressed as the velocity of climate change per unit of time (Zachos et al., 2001; Galvan et al., 2025). Second, the climatic instability, expressed as variation in climate within each geological period (Vrba, 1992; Dynesius & Jansson, 2000; Finnegan et al., 2015).  The Neogene (23Ma – 2Ma), saw the emergence of many modern plant and animal families, as well as the extinction of many others that were previously widespread during the Paleogene (66Ma – 23 Ma) (Costeur et al., 2004). During this period, the Earth’s climate transitioned from a greenhouse to an icehouse state, culminating in the onset of the Northern Hemisphere glaciation around 2-3 million Ma (Kennett et al., 1995). Climate change magnitude and climate instability across the Neogene could have jointly shaped the assembly of regional biodiversity via their influence on dispersal, speciation and extinction dynamics (Erwin 2009; Ding et al. 2025; neubauer2022short?)
High climate change magnitude could increase change in the composition of regional biotas by triggering speciation events and/or increasing extinctions rates.  Climate-driven species factories (Stebbins 1974; Bernor et al., 1996; Eronen et al., 2012) can emerge in regions with high climate change magnitude (such as increasing aridity or cooling), where preadapted taxa gain a competitive advantage, diversify, and give rise to new lineages suited to the conditions of the near future. For example, during the gradual cooling of Earth during the Neogene (23Ma – 2Ma), ecosystems transition from warm evergreen subtropical woodlands to cooler, more seasonal deciduous forests (Jablonski, 2008; Barnosky et al., 2011; Reddin et al., 2020), many forest-adapted mammal taxa declined or went extinct, while open-habitat specialists such as bovids and equids expanded through adaptive radiations driven by ecological specialization (Jernvall & Fortelius 2002; Raia et al. 2011).  As North America became drier than Eurasia during the middle Miocene–Pliocene, arid-adapted groups such as horses, camels, and canids evolved there first and later invaded the Old World.  In addition, directional shifts in climate change such as the transitions between prolonged warming and cooling phases (or vice versa) can precipitate extinction cascades but also promote adaptive reorganizations (Pinsky et al., 2025; Lewthwaite et al., 2017; Kiessling et al., 2024) depending on how rapidly populations and traits respond to the climatic change shift (Benton & Pearson, 2001; Pimm et al., 1988). Morphological and genetic data show that climate-driven changes in temperature, aridity, and productivity influence body size, tooth morphology, and dispersal, often with temporal lags in the evolutionary response (MacFadden, 2000; Hadly et al., 2004), making transitional periods especially prone to ecological disequilibrium and elevated turnover (Guerin et al., 2013; Fitzpatrick et al., 2013).
In contrast to climate-driven species factories, low turnover rates are expected within climatically stable regions. In climatically stable regions, extinction and speciation rates tend to be lower due to species populations being less fragmented and experiencing homogeneous environmental pressures (Vasconcelos et al., 2021). Turnover may be driven mainly by species immigrants seeking refuge away from regions with periods of intense climatic change (Fortelius & Zhang, 2006; Casanovas-Vilar et al., 2010; Vasconcelos et al., 2021). For instance, during the Miocene (23Ma-5Ma), the Iberian Peninsula acted as a climatic oasis where suids, bovids, and small carnivores persisted after going extinct elsewhere in Europe (Casanovas-Vilar et al., 2010; Fortelius et al., 2014). Its stable climate led to low turnover, with most newcomers arriving via dispersal from Africa or Central Europe rather than local speciation (Agustí & Antón, 2002). In contrast to species factories, which are macroevolutionary sources of diversification (Fortelius et al., 2014), climatically stable regions act as macroevolutionary sinks, preserving past diversity with limited contribution to future radiations (Stebbins 1974; Fortelius et al., 2014; Mirzaie Ataabadi et al., 2013; Vasconcelos et al., 2021).
Here, we examine alternative hypotheses regarding the role of climate dynamics in driving the turnover of mammalian fossil assemblage during the Neogene (Figure 1). Specifically, A) regions experiencing low levels of directional climatic change (i.e. magnitude) and high levels of instability are expected to show minimal fossil turnover (Figure 1a.A, Figure 1b.A) (H1-stability), whereas those experiencing B) a high magnitude of climate change and low instability are expected to show elevated rates of turnover. (Figure 1a.B, Figure 1b.B) (H2-directional change). Finally, C) a low magnitude of climate change and high instability may generate episodic pulses of turnover without sustained faunal replacement (Figure 1a.C, Figure 1b.C) (H3-Oscillatory climate). D) When both climatic magnitude and instability are high, their effects may compound, producing accelerated and recurrent turnover as ecosystems experience rapid and irregular environmental shifts. (Figure 1a.D, Figure 1b.D) (H4- compound instability).

3.2 Methods

3.2.1 Fossil and paleoclimate data sources

3.2.1.1 Fossil occurrence data
We gathered large-mammal fossil data from the NOW database (Vzliobaite et al., 2023). Fossils of large mammals are particularly useful to uncover macro-evolutionary trends as they can preserve biogeographical patterns with high spatial fidelity (Darroch et al., 2021). Moreover, the results of centuries of paleontological research are now digitally available in aggregated fossil databases with standardized taxonomic nomenclature and geotagged records. Our queried subset of the database contained 18349 species level fossil records spanning six (6) mammal orders: Artiodactyla (40%), Carnivora (26%), Perissodactylia (24%), Primates (1.5%), and Proboscidea (8.6%). We excluded records a) georeferenced outside the North America and Europe continents (3068 records), and b) where the genus was classified as indeterminate (“indet.”) (4215 records). We ended with a total of 11066 species level fossil records (Table S1).To reduce taxonomic bias in sampling completeness we focused subsequent analyses in records aggregated to the genus level, obtaining a total of unique 6843 genus-level fossil space-time observations.


3.2.1.2 Defining the temporal and spatial scope of fossil records
Temporally, we binned individual fossil records to their corresponding Neogene epochs based on the mid-point between the maximum and minimum radiocarbon-based age estimates that are reported in the NOW database. We consider the following temporal boundaries to the Neogene epochs: The Aquitanian (23–21 Ma), Burdigalian (20–16 Ma), Langhian (15–14 Ma) and Serravallian (13–12 Ma), Tortonian (11–8 Ma), and Messinian (7–5 Ma), Zanclean (5–4 Ma) and Piacenzian (3–2 Ma) (Kennett et al., 1995).
Spatially, we used the ‘grid’ method to transform present-day geographic fossil coordinates and associated age estimates were projected to a discrete global grid defined separately for each Neogene epoch. These time-specific grids were rotated in one-million-year increments across the Phanerozoic (540–0 Ma) using the MERDITH2021 plate reconstruction model (Merdith et al. 2021; Jones et al., 2024), thereby correcting for underlying plate tectonic shifts in deep time and generating paleo-coordinates for all fossil observations.  To do this, we used the paleorotate() function from the paleoverse R package v1.4.0 (Jones et al., 2023) (Figure S1).


3.2.1.3 Defining fossil paleo-assemblages
We used a hexagonal equal-area grid to assign fossil paleo coordinates to spatial bins representing fossil paleo-assemblages within each Neogene epoch. Specifically, we counted unique fossil observations within each hexagonal cell of resolution number 3 from Uber’s H3 geospatial indexing library (i.e. with an average spacing between adjacent cells of 103.6Km). This method was implemented with the bin_space() function of the paleoverse R package (v1.4.0). We filtered out those fossil paleo-assemblages containing less than three (3) Genera. This aggregation yielded 451 unique paleo-assemblages (Figure S2).

3.2.1.3.1 Paleo-atmospheric temperature data
We utilized paleo-atmospheric temperature reconstructions for the Northern Hemisphere (Hagen et al., 2019) as a proxy for macro-scale climatic variation across continental regions in space and Neogene across time. The dataset from Hagen et al. (2019) spans the Cenozoic (60 Ma to the present), and we extracted a subset corresponding to the temporal range of our fossil data. We aligned the spatial resolution of the climate data with that of our fossil paleo-assemblages by calculating simple means within each hexagonal grid cell. We created a raster stack for the Neogene (23–2 Ma) where each layer represented 1Ma (Figure S3).



3.2.1.4 Defining climate change variables

3.2.1.4.1 Calculating climate change magnitude and instability
To understand the environmental context in which fossil communities evolved, we summarized atmospheric temperature climate change across the Neogene within continental regions, separating long-term warming or cooling between epochs from short-term temperature variability within epochs.
First, we estimated the magnitude of climate change between consecutive Neogene epochs  by extracting the raster values from each corresponding layer of the paleo-atmospheric temperature raster stack into a matrix form, with rows representing spatial grid cells and columns representing individual time points (Figure 2B). We conducted a linear regression for each grid cell individually, regressing temperature values against time for a given Neogene epoch. The coefficient extracted from each regression represents the magnitude of temperature change (slope). Positive slope values indicate warming trends whereas negative slope values indicate cooling trends (Figure 2C).
Second, we quantified climate instability by calculating the coefficient of variation (CV) of atmospheric temperature for each grid cell over each Neogene epoch. Specifically, we computed the ratio of the standard deviation to the mean temperature (adjusted to Kelvin by adding 273.15) for each hexagonal grid cell across each Neogene epoch (Figure 2D).


3.2.1.4.2 Defining spatial & temporal climate change regions
We identified regions with similar patterns of climate change in space and time to enable climate-based regional fauna comparison within continents across the entire Neogene. We started with a multiband raster stack were each layer represented the mean atmospheric temperature of continental raster pixels for each Neogene epoch. Then, we reduced dimensionality with Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to capture dominant spatiotemporal gradients of atmospheric temperature variation across the Neogene. Specifically, we used the rasterPCA() function from the RStoolbox package which perform PCA directly on raster objects by treating each pixel as an observation and each raster layer as a variable (Leutner et al., 2018). From this new multiband raster stack, we extracted the first three principal components (PC1–PC3) and rescaled them to a [0,1] range. The first 3 PCA axes summarized 98.9% of the variance present in the mean atmospheric temperature raster stack. The first component alone comprised 89.9% of the variance with the second and third components making up for the 6.3% and 2.7% respectively.  After, we clustered continental regions with similar temporal climatic dynamics with k-means across a range of cluster numbers (k = 3 to 7). The optimal number of clusters was selected by maximizing within-group dispersion, as evaluated by the Calinski-Harabasz criterion (Figure 2A; Figure S4).



3.2.1.5 Inferring biodiversity assembly processes in deep time

3.2.1.5.1 Building a paleo-assemblage community network
To large scale biogeographical patterns through deep time, we linked fossil paleo-assemblages in the Neogene based on the similarity of their fossil composition.  We represented this linkage as a bipartite network representing the presence (1) or absence (0) of each genus across all defined paleo-assemblages (i.e., unique combinations of hexagonal grid cells and Neogene epochs). We obtained the unipartite projection of these bipartite network by calculating the compositional dissimilarity between paleo assemblages. Specifically, we calculated Simpson dissimilarity between every paleo-assemblage pair with the beta.sim() component of the beta.pair() function in the betapart R package. Simpson turnover index emphasizes species turnover by accounting for differences in shared taxa without being influenced by nestedness effects, making it well-suited for detecting true compositional replacement (Baselga et al., 2013) and provides a more reliable basis for tracking large-scale biogeographical patterns in the fossil record.  The resulting squared matrix of pairwise dissimilarities between paleo-assemblages served as the foundation for network construction (Figure S5).


3.2.1.5.2 Delineating paleobiogeographic clusters in space and time
We used a stochastic block modelling (SBM) to delineate coherent paleobiogeographic regions across the Neogene. Stochastic block modelling (SBM) is a non-parametric statistical method that identifies groups within a network. The model inputs the paleo-assemblage dissimilarity matrix and outputs a) a vector of group labels assigning every paleoassemblage to a group (i.e. paleobiogeographic cluster), and b) connectivity (omega) matrix summarizing the degree of compositional dissimilarity within and between paleobiogeographic clusters (Figure S7). The SBM summarized the fossil paleo assemblage dissimilarity matrix and converged in a set of 40 paleobiogeographic clusters each representing a group of spatiotemporally cohesive and ecologically similar fossil paleo-assemblages. These paleo-biogeographic regions each represented in average ~11 fossil paleo-assemblages, ranging from 2 to 22. Europe had 25 paleobiogeographic regions where while 15 belonged to North America. 
We employed spectral clustering for SBM model initialization, which improves convergence and stability for large networks. Spatial and Temporal distance matrices were used to inform the SBM’s prior structure, enabling it to partition assemblages into groups that not only share ecological similarity but are also proximally located in space and/or time. Models were fitted across a range (0-60) of candidate cluster numbers (K), and the optimal number of groups was selected based on the Integrated Completed Likelihood (ICL) criterion (Figure S6). This criterion balances model fit and parsimony, penalizing overly complex models while favoring those that capture robust structure. Spatial distances were computed as great-circle distances (in kilometers) between the paleocoordinates (rotated to their Neogene positions) of each assemblage using the earth.dist() function from the fossil R package (Vavrek et al, 2020). Temporal distances were calculated as absolute differences (in millions of years) between the midpoint ages assigned to each Neogene epoch or each paleo-assemblage (Figure S7).  


3.2.1.5.3 Linking climate change to fossil paleobiogeographic region dissimilarity
To obtain an standardized measure of the overall compositional heterogeneity within a window of space and time (i.e. beta-diversity), we calculated the mean of the diagonal elements of the corresponding omega submatrix, considering only the subset of paleobiogeographic clusters assigned to a given climate change region and Neogene epoch combination. In total we obtained 80 standardized measurements. We kept the number of contributing fossil assemblages and the variability of these submatrix diagonal summaries for use as model weights. We also recorded among-region dissimilarity from the corresponding off-diagonal paleobiogeographic cluster entries, but we did not consider them for further analysis.
We used beta-regression modelling to estimate the relationship between our standardized beta-diversity metric to a) the absolute magnitude of climatic change, b) the direction of the temperature trend (i.e. change slope sign - cooling (-) vs warming (+) ), c) climatic stability, and d) continent affiliation. Climate change magnitude and climatic instability predictor variables were scaled for comparability, and regions with more sampling effort were given greater weight based on the number of individual fossil observations (Supplementary text S1). Overall, we fitted a set of four beta-regression models with progressive degrees of complexity. The baseline model (Null model) included only the main effects of climate‐change magnitude and instability. Geographic structure was introduced in (Continental Model) by allowing both effects to vary by continent. Model (Continental Climate Sensitivity Model) further accounted for compound instability (the magnitude × instability interaction) and relaxed the assumption of constant variance by modeling the precision (dispersion (ϕ) component) of the beta-regression model response as a function of both instability and continent. This allowed the model to reflect that turnover patterns may be more variable under unstable climates and may differ in consistency between Europe and North America. In addition, site-based weights were applied to correct for uneven sampling intensity across bins. The most complex model (Directional Climate Response Model) added warming–cooling asymmetry (magnitude × direction). This explicitly tested whether large magnitudes of climatic change had stronger biodiversity effects under warming versus cooling episodes. Continent interactions with all predictors allowed for geographic contrasts in these dynamics. Model comparisons were evaluated using the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC). Finally, we regressed turnover predictions from the best-fit model against geological time age using a loess smoothed function to identify the trajectory of turnover across 1Ma time intervals.

3.3 Results

3.3.1 The diversity of fossil paleoassemblages
For all fossil paleo assemblages, genus richness per cell averaged approximately 14, with values ranging from 4 to 68. Across all Neogene epochs, the Burdigalian and Serravallian epoch exhibited the highest mean fossil richness, each averaging 16 genera per cell. The Langhian followed with a mean of 15, while the Tortonian and Messinian epochs showed means of 14 and 13, respectively. The Aquitanian and Piacenzian epoch recorded slightly lower averages, with 11 and 12 genera per cell. The Zanclean epoch had the lowest mean richness at 10 genera per cell. Minimum richness was consistent across all intervals at 4 genera per cell, while maximum values varied from 27 in the Zanclean to 68 in the Tortonian.


3.3.2 Climate change across spatiotemporal climatic zones
Across climatic zones, temperature change and instability varied markedly within and between continents (Figure 3). In North America, climatic slopes showed a wider range, with higher median values in zones 2 and 4 (up to ~0.25 °C Ma⁻¹) and greater dispersion compared to other zones, indicating more pronounced directional shifts. Europe, in contrast, displayed generally lower and more consistent slopes across all zones (~0.10–0.15 °C Ma⁻¹). Patterns of climatic instability followed a similar structure: in North America, variability was higher overall, while Europe showed lower median instability and narrower ranges across zones. (Figure 3).



Figure 2: Spatiotemporal climatic zones and their temporal dynamics in North America and Europe during the Neogene (23–2 Ma). Climatic zones were identified as PCA-based clusters of contiguous regions with similar temporal trajectories of mean atmospheric temperature dynamics. (A) Geographic distribution of the five zones, color-coded from brown (Zone 1) to green (Zone 5). (B) Absolute temperature values (°C) averaged per zone and plotted across Neogene epochs. (C) Zone-specific trajectories of temperature change magnitude and plotted across Neogene epochs. (D) Climatic instability (relative variability of temperature) and plotted across epochs. For line plots, colored curves correspond to climatic zones, with epoch along the x-axis (yellow bar). Vertical dashed lines indicate the approximate peak of the Miocene Climatic Optimum (MMCO).


Five (5) climate change clusters best represented the spatial patterns of climate change dynamics contained in the paleoclimatic PCA. (Figure 2). The first climate change cluster span western Europe and low-latitude North America, where atmospheric temperature remained stable with minimal variability. The second climate change cluster was in northern Africa, California, and south of Florida, and showed a pattern of early warming followed by cooling, with increasing variability in Europe after 10 Ma. The third climate change cluster covered Russia, the Alps, and northeastern North America. This one displayed strong directional change, mid-Miocene cooling followed by European warming. The fourth climate change cluster, found in central North America, eastern Europe, and the steppes, was the most variable, with a major warming spike in the late Miocene to early Pliocene. Finally, the fifth climate change cluster, in northwestern North America, cooled early and later stabilized, with a milder warming–cooling cycle in Europe.


3.3.3 Inferring biodiversity assembly processes in deep time
Fossil assemblages within a paleobiogeographic cluster shared on average about 40 % of their genera with other paleobiogeographic clusters in the same Neogene epoch. In North America, turnover was more heterogeneous across climate change clusters relative to Europe. We found strong evidence supporting the directional change hypothesis (H2), with opposite responses to warming and cooling between continents. In North America, rapid warming of about +0.25 °C Ma⁻¹ increased turnover by roughly 7%, whereas in Europe, equivalent warming reduced turnover by around 10%, indicating divergent biogeographic responses to directional climate forcing. We also found partial support for the oscillatory climate hypothesis (H3): climatic instability, approximately 0.1% higher relative temperature variability, slightly reduced turnover in Europe but increased it by up to 5% in North America. However, these effects weakened once climatic direction was modeled separately, suggesting that instability alone does not drive faunal reorganization. Finally, we found little evidence for the compound instability hypothesis (H4); instead, extremes of high magnitude and strong instability buffered turnover (Figure 4).
The Compound Instability Model and the Directional Climate Response Model consistently show that Neogene faunal turnover was shaped by the combined effects of long-term temperature trends and short-term climatic instability, with outcomes differing between continents. In North America, positive directional trends of about +0.25 °C per Ma or more unstable climates (≈ 0.11% higher relative temperature variability) each raised turnover by roughly 4–5%, reducing the proportion of genera shared among fossil assemblages. In Europe, turnover was overall higher but less sensitive to climatic fluctuations. Stronger temperature trends or instability slightly decreased turnover (by about 1–2%). When the direction of temperature change was explicitly included, the Directional Climate Response Model revealed that warming periods reduced turnover in Europe by roughly 10%, while increased it in North America by about 7%. High absolute temperature changes combined with strong instability produced a net buffering effect (≈ −11%).
Overall model performance improved markedly from R² ≈ 0.08 (Compound Instability Model) to R² ≈ 0.42 (Directional Climate Response Model) (Table 1). When examining the results of the best fit model across time, In North America, during the Aquitanian–Burdigalian, turnover remained moderate (~0.62–0.64) under relatively stable climatic conditions. Across the Langhian–Serravallian, turnover peaked (~0.68–0.70) as the dashed line indicates a shift toward stronger warming trends (up to +0.25 °C Ma⁻¹) and higher climatic instability (~0.002–0.0025). Through the Tortonian, turnover declined sharply (~0.60), while both warming and instability subsided. A second, smaller rise in turnover occurred during the Messinian, preceding a strong cooling phase (~ –0.4 °C Ma⁻¹) and reduced instability (~0.001), after which turnover fell to its lowest levels in the Zanclean–Piacenzian (~0.57), marking a period of climatic stabilization toward the Pliocene. In Europe, turnover remained comparatively stable (~0.60–0.65) across epochs but exhibited a gradual, low-amplitude rise after the Miocene Climatic Optimum (MCO). During the Aquitanian–Burdigalian, both turnover and climatic variables were low and steady, with slopes near 0 °C Ma⁻¹ and instability with an SD close to 0.1% of its mean. Through the Langhian–Serravallian, turnover modestly increased (~0.62–0.64) as the dashed line shows mild cooling (–0.1 to –0.2 °C Ma⁻¹). The Tortonian–Messinian interval marked a slight rebound in temperature trends toward neutral to weak warming (~+0.15 °C Ma⁻¹) and minimal instability variation. By the Pliocene, turnover rose to its highest levels (~0.65) under moderate warming (~+0.2 °C Ma⁻¹) and low climatic variability with SD (~0.1% – 0.15%) of their means (Figure 4).

title: Conclusion
text:
This thesis shows that ecological structure is not a single property that changes in parallel with species composition, but a multidimensional outcome constrained by processes operating across scales. Biodiversity change is often described in terms of species gains, losses, and turnover, yet these compositional changes only partially capture how ecosystems reorganize. Across contemporary multitrophic networks and deep-time fossil assemblages, this work demonstrates that ecological structure can be conserved despite substantial species turnover, or rapidly reorganized following relatively small compositional changes. These patterns arise because ecological structure is shaped by multiple layers of constraints that determine which traits, interactions, and organizational forms are possible.
A central contribution of this thesis is to clarify how different processes constrain different dimensions of ecological structure. Evolutionary processes constrain the availability of traits and functional roles through speciation, extinction, and adaptation. Regional climatic and biogeographic processes constrain which subsets of this trait space can persist locally. Local demographic and community assembly processes further constrain which species can co-occur, persist, and dominate under given environmental conditions. Finally, interaction assembly processes constrain which species interact and how those interactions are organized into networks. These layers do not act independently: constraints imposed at one level shape the expression of constraints at other levels, and feedbacks across levels can amplify, dampen, or redirect ecological reorganization.
By applying this layered perspective across space and time, the thesis shows that environmental change alters which constraints matter most, rather than producing uniform ecological responses. In contemporary multitrophic systems, climatic gradients reshuffle the relative strength of bottom-up and top-down constraints, generating predictable changes in trait distributions and interaction structure without necessarily altering species richness. In deep time, similar climatic drivers produced contrasting outcomes across continents because they interacted with different evolutionary histories, regional species pools, and prior assembly trajectories. These results demonstrate that ecological structure is contingent on historical and biogeographic context, and that environmental forcing alone cannot explain patterns of biodiversity reorganization.
Together, these findings advance ecology by reframing biodiversity change as a problem of constrained emergence. Ecological structure emerges from the intersection of multiple assembly processes, each restricting the space of possible community configurations. Understanding biodiversity change therefore requires identifying how constraints shift, interact, and propagate across scales, rather than focusing solely on changes in species composition or network patterns. By integrating traits, interactions, networks, and deep-time dynamics within a single process-based framework, this thesis provides a coherent approach for studying how ecological systems are assembled, maintained, and reorganized. This perspective offers a stronger foundation for predicting ecosystem responses to ongoing global change, particularly in a world where environmental conditions are shifting faster than the processes that generate ecological structure can equilibrate.

title: Appendix A — Trait-based inference of ecological network assembly
text:
A.1 Simulating resource-consumer network assembly
We applied our conceptual framework to assess the influence of community and interaction assembly processes on network structure. To this end, we simulated the assembly of probabilistic bipartite networks under different combinations of stochastic and deterministic (trait-based) assembly processes within and between trophic levels (Figure 2 in the main text; Table S1). Trait-based simulations of network assembly allow exploring the relationships between trait based assembly processes and emergent network structures. Moreover, simulations help to avoid empirical biases when inferring network assembly processes. Such biasses include correlations among traits and potentially hidden traits and niches when testing for neutrality or environmental filtering (Barabás et al. 2013). Below we describe the steps we followed for a trait-based simulation of network assembly processes:
