C.2.1 Temporal binning of climatic rasters (1 Ma) within Neogene stages
Paleoclimate reconstructions were organized into discrete, stage-specific climate stacks by binning rasters at 1 Ma resolution within each Neogene stage (Aquitanian–Piacenzian). For each stage, we identified all paleoatmospheric temperature rasters whose time stamps fell within that stage’s chronostratigraphic boundaries and grouped them into a single multi-layer object (e.g., “Temp.1”, “Temp.2”, … in Fig. S3). This procedure preserves within-stage temporal information while ensuring that all climatic summaries are computed from time slices that are chronologically consistent with the fossil data assigned to that stage. Because stages differ in duration, the number of 1 Ma rasters per stage varies, reflecting the amount of temporal coverage available within each interval.



**Figure S3. Paleotemperature reconstructions for the Neogene.** Spatial reconstructions of paleoatmospheric temperature for eight Neogene stages (Aquitanian–Piacenzian), shown separately for North America and Europe. For each stage, multiple temperature layers (“Temp” fields) represent alternative reconstructions or time slices within the stage, capturing spatial heterogeneity and within-stage climatic variability. Color scales denote reconstructed temperature (°C), illustrating the persistence and evolution of large-scale temperature gradients through the Neogene.


These stage-specific raster stacks were subsequently used to derive three complementary climatic descriptors for each grid cell: (i) the mean temperature across all 1 Ma slices within the stage (capturing average climatic conditions), (ii) the temporal slope of temperature through the stage (capturing directional change), and (iii) temporal instability, quantified as within-stage variability among 1 Ma slices (capturing fluctuations around the mean). These variables capture average conditions, directional climatic change, and within-stage variability, respectively, and together describe the climatic context experienced by fossil assemblages. Together, this temporal binning strategy allows climate to be summarized in a way that matches the temporal granularity of Neogene stages while retaining meaningful information on both climatic trends and variability within each stage.

C.2.1.1 Mean atmospheric temperature



**Figure X. Mean atmospheric temperature across Neogene stages.** Panels show the mean reconstructed atmospheric temperature for each Neogene stage (Aquitanian–Piacenzian), obtained by averaging paleoatmospheric temperature layers within each stage. Maps are shown for North America and Europe, with colors indicating temperature in °C. The figure summarizes broad-scale spatial temperature gradients and their temporal evolution through the Neogene, providing a baseline climatic context for subsequent analyses.




C.2.1.2 Temporal slope of atmospheric temperature (Magnitude & Direction Climate Change)



**Figure X. Mean atmospheric temperature across Neogene stages.** Panels show the mean reconstructed atmospheric temperature for each Neogene stage (Aquitanian–Piacenzian), obtained by averaging paleoatmospheric temperature layers within each stage. Maps are shown for North America and Europe, with colors indicating temperature in °C. The figure summarizes broad-scale spatial temperature gradients and their temporal evolution through the Neogene, providing a baseline climatic context for subsequent analyses.




C.2.1.3 Temporal instability of atmospheric temperature



**Figure X. Temporal instability of atmospheric temperature across Neogene stages.** Panels depict the temporal instability of reconstructed atmospheric temperature for each Neogene stage (Aquitanian–Piacenzian), quantified as the within-stage variability among paleoatmospheric temperature layers. Higher values (warm colors) indicate greater temporal variability, whereas lower values (cool colors) reflect more stable climatic conditions. The figure illustrates spatial heterogeneity in climatic stability through the Neogene and provides a complementary metric to mean temperature and temporal slope patterns.





C.2.2 Delineating paleoclimatic zones
Paleoclimatic zones were delineated to identify spatially and temporally coherent units of climatic conditions across the Neogene. For each grid cell and Neogene stage, we summarized paleoclimate using three complementary descriptors derived from the 1 Ma–binned mean atmospheric temperature rasters. To reduce dimensionality and account for covariance among climatic descriptors, we applied principal component analysis (PCA) to the standardized climate variables across all grid cells and stages. The leading principal components, which captured the majority of climatic variation, were retained and used as inputs for clustering.



**Figure X. Variance explained by principal components of paleoclimatic variables.** Bar plot showing the variance explained by each principal component derived from the paleoclimatic dataset. The first component accounts for the majority of the total variance, whereas subsequent components explain progressively smaller proportions, indicating that most large-scale climatic variation through the Neogene is captured along a dominant primary gradient.





**Figure X. Spatial patterns of principal components of temporal temperature instability.** Maps show the spatial loadings of the first eight principal components (PC1–PC8) derived from the temporal instability of atmospheric temperature across the Neogene. PC1 captures the dominant large-scale gradient in climatic instability, whereas higher-order components explain progressively finer-scale or weaker spatial structure. Color scales indicate the magnitude and direction of component loadings, illustrating how major modes of climatic instability are distributed across North America and Europe.


Paleoclimatic zones were then defined using k-means clustering in this reduced climatic space, grouping grid cells with similar climatic histories across space and time. The optimal number of clusters was selected based on the Calinski–Harabasz criterion, balancing within-cluster homogeneity and between-cluster separation.



**Figure X. Comparison of K-means clustering solutions and selection of the optimal number of clusters.** The left panel shows K-means partitions of objects for solutions with increasing numbers of clusters (k), illustrating how group membership changes as k increases. The right panel reports the Calinski–Harabasz criterion for each k, with the highlighted point indicating the optimal clustering solution based on the maximum criterion value. Together, these panels justify the choice of k used in subsequent analyses.


Resulting clusters represent climatic spatiotemporal zones that integrate both geographic structure and temporal climatic dynamics. Each grid cell–stage combination was assigned to a climatic spatiotemporal zone. This grouping captures shared climatic histories and provides a way to account for spatial autocorrelation, given that nearby grid cells tend to exhibit similar climatic trajectories through time.



**Figure X. Climatic spatiotemporal zones derived from multivariate clustering.** Hexagonal grid cells across North America and Europe are classified into five climatic spatiotemporal zones based on multivariate climate characteristics through the Neogene. Colors denote cluster membership (zones 1–5), capturing coherent regions that integrate both spatial structure and temporal climatic dynamics. Unfilled hexagons indicate areas without sufficient data coverage. The map illustrates broad-scale climatic regionalization used to define comparative units in subsequent analyses.

C.3 Evaluating fossil dissimilarity
Compositional dissimilarity among fossil assemblages was quantified to characterize spatial and temporal variation in taxonomic composition across the Neogene. For each pair of paleoassemblages, we calculated taxonomic dissimilarity using presence–absence data at the genus level. Assemblages were defined as unique combinations of spatial grid cells and Neogene stages, ensuring that dissimilarity comparisons reflected both spatial and temporal separation.
We used the Simpson dissimilarity index (β_SIM) to quantify compositional turnover between assemblages. β_SIM emphasizes taxon replacement while minimizing the influence of differences in richness, making it well suited for fossil data where sampling intensity varies among assemblages.



**Figure X. Pairwise compositional dissimilarity among paleoassemblages.** Heat map showing pairwise Simpson dissimilarity (β_SIM) between all paleoassemblages, where values range from 0 (identical composition) to 1 (complete turnover). Warmer colors indicate greater compositional dissimilarity. Block-like structure along the diagonal reflects groups of paleoassemblages with relatively similar taxonomic composition, whereas high off-diagonal values indicate strong turnover between assemblages separated in space and/or time.


The nestedness-resultant component (β_SNE), reflects turnover-driven differences from those arising through nested subsets of taxa and can be more sensitive to differences in sampling completeness. We don’t consider (β_SNE) in our subsequent analyses.



**Figure X. Pairwise compositional dissimilarity due to nestedness among paleoassemblages.** Heat map showing pairwise nestedness-resultant dissimilarity (β_SNE) between all paleoassemblages. Values range from 0 (no nestedness difference) to 1 (strong nestedness-driven dissimilarity), with warmer colors indicating greater nestedness effects. Overall low β_SNE values indicate that most compositional differences among paleoassemblages are driven by species turnover rather than nestedness.


We used multidimensional ordination (NMDS) to visualize major gradients in paleoassemblage composition.



Figure S2: Ordination of mammalian fossil assemblages using NMDS based on genus composition across Neogene time intervals. Colors denote geological age (Ma), and shapes distinguish continents. The ordination shows a clear temporal gradient and gradual compositional separation between faunas of Europe and North America.

C.5 Evaluating the relationship between turnover and climate

C.5.1 Spatial join between climatic variables with fossil localities
For each paleoassemblage, climatic values were extracted from the raster cell corresponding to the assemblage’s grid cell centroid.



**Figure X. Relationship between climatic change magnitude and climatic instability.** Scatter plot showing the association between the magnitude of climatic change and climatic instability across paleoassemblages. Points represent individual paleoassemblages, with symbols indicating continent (Europe vs. North America). Climatic instability increases with the absolute magnitude of climatic change, producing a characteristic V-shaped pattern that reflects greater temporal variability under both strong warming and strong cooling regimes.




C.5.2 Subset the dissimilarity matrix
To quantify compositional turnover within climatic spatiotemporal zones, we subset the global paleoassemblage dissimilarity matrix according to climatic cluster membership and time region. The full matrix contains pairwise Simpson dissimilarity (β_SIM) values between all paleoassemblages. For each climatic cluster and Neogene stage (or time region), we extracted the submatrix corresponding only to paleoassemblages belonging to that cluster–time combination.



**Figure X. Clustered compositional dissimilarity among climatic spatiotemporal zones.** Heat map displays pairwise compositional dissimilarity between climatic spatiotemporal zones, with rows and columns ordered by hierarchical clustering. Dendrograms summarize similarity relationships among zones, highlighting groups of zones with relatively similar taxonomic composition. Color intensity reflects the magnitude of dissimilarity, with lighter colors indicating greater similarity and darker colors indicating stronger compositional differentiation among zones.



C.5.2.1 Extract the diagonal of the matrix subset and get its mean
To summarize within-zone compositional turnover quantitatively, we extracted the diagonal of each subset matrix and calculated its mean. This mean dissimilarity represents the average compositional turnover among paleoassemblages within a given climatic spatiotemporal zone. These values provide a standardized measure of internal turnover that can be compared across zones and through time.



**Figure X. Distribution of turnover among climatic spatiotemporal zones.** Histogram showing the distribution of compositional turnover values across climatic spatiotemporal zones. The red vertical line indicates the mean turnover. The distribution illustrates substantial variation in turnover among zones, with most values clustered at intermediate levels and a smaller number of zones exhibiting high compositional turnover.





C.5.3 Repeat for all climatic clusters across all time bins
We repeated the procedure for all climatic spatiotemporal zone and Neogene stage combinations. In addition to mean, we calculated the standard deviation to capture the variance.



**Figure X. Temporal patterns of compositional turnover across climatic clusters.** Points show mean compositional turnover values for climatic clusters through time, plotted against geological age (Ma). Vertical dashed lines indicate Neogene stage boundaries. Symbols denote different climatic clusters, illustrating both within-stage variability and among-cluster differences in turnover. The figure reveals temporal structure in turnover dynamics, with distinct climatic clusters exhibiting different magnitudes and trajectories of compositional change across the Neogene.





**Figure X. Temporal variation in the variability of compositional turnover across climatic clusters.** Points show the standard deviation of compositional turnover within climatic clusters through time, plotted against geological age (Ma). Vertical dashed lines indicate Neogene stage boundaries, and symbols distinguish climatic clusters. Higher values indicate greater within-cluster variability in turnover, revealing differences in the stability and heterogeneity of compositional change among climatic clusters across the Neogene.




C.5.4 Beta-regression modelling
The beta regression model is fitted with a logit link and that for our project answers the following question.
How does mean turnover (bounded 0–1) respond to the magnitude of atmospheric temperature change, its direction (warming vs cooling), and instability, and do these relationships differ by continent?






Using the following general formula
\(y_i = \beta(u_i\phi, (1-u_i)\phi), \space logit(u_i) = n_i\)
where:
\(u_i = \mathbb{E}(y_i)\) is the mean turnover, with \(y_i\)​ is the observed mean turnover,
\(n_i\) is the linear predictor, and \(\phi\) is constant.
Taking Europe as the baseline continent and cooling as the baseline direction of temperature change, the linear predictor is
\[ n_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1|Slope_i| + \beta_2Warming_i + \beta_3Instability_i + \beta_4|Slope_i| \times Warming_i + \beta_5|Slope_i| \times Instability_i + \beta_6Continent_i + \beta_7|Slope_i| \times Continent_i \]




C.5.4.1 Beta regression model diagnosis
Model adequacy was evaluated using standardized weighted residuals. Residuals were plotted against fitted values to assess potential deviations from model assumptions. The absence of systematic patterns or trends and the approximately symmetric distribution of residuals around zero indicate an adequate model fit and no strong evidence of heteroscedasticity or misspecification on the response scale.



**Figure X. Residual diagnostics for the beta regression model.** Plot of standardized weighted residuals against fitted values for the beta regression model. The absence of systematic patterns or trends and the roughly symmetric distribution of residuals around zero indicate an adequate model fit and no strong evidence of heteroscedasticity or misspecification on the response scale.




C.5.4.2 Beta regression model predictions



Figure 3: Compositional turnover variation across five climatic zones in North America and Europe during the Neogene. Boxplots show the distribution of turnover values (0–1) estimated for fossil assemblages within each climatic zone. Compositional turnover reflects the average turnover between fossil assemblages within paleobiogeographic regions for each climatic zone, measured at the Genus level





**Figure X. Predicted compositional turnover as a function of climate change magnitude and climatic instability.** Panels show model-predicted turnover across gradients of climate change magnitude and climatic instability for two climatic clusters (panels 1 and 2). Colored surfaces represent predicted turnover values from the beta regression model, with warmer colors indicating higher turnover, and white contour lines indicating equal predicted turnover. Points show observed data. The figure illustrates how turnover increases nonlinearly with both the magnitude of climatic change and climatic instability, with differences in response surfaces between clusters.





**Figure X. Predicted compositional turnover under cooling and warming regimes.** Panels show model-predicted compositional turnover as a function of the absolute magnitude of climate change (|slope|) and climatic instability, stratified by climatic cluster (columns 1–2) and by the direction of temperature change (cooling: top row; warming: bottom row). Colored surfaces represent predicted turnover from the beta regression model, with contour lines indicating equal predicted values and points showing observed data. Dashed lines mark zero climatic instability and the boundary between cooling and warming regimes. The figure illustrates asymmetric turnover responses to warming versus cooling and differences in sensitivity among climatic clusters.
